description.narrative: Oxfam Uganda and Chapter four will strengthen the capacity of both staff and partners on recent legislations restrictions and theirimplications on CSOs operations as well as on institutional and personal security. This will be done through conducting two trainings in the period from February till May for 50 local organisations. These organisations will have increased their skills on data security, personal and institutional security management; development of security plans. This project will contribute to Oxfam's Uganda's larger aim to increase in 3 years# time the enabling environment for civic action, political participation and improved engagement between citizens, CSOs, NGOs and the government in Uganda.

participating-org.narrative:
Chapter Four Uganda was formed in 2013 after a study was done in Uganda and it revealed that there were big gaps in enforcement of civil liberties and majority of the organizations in Uganda were focused on economic and social cultural rights hence the gap. The organisation was started to offer legal response to civic ators as a way to promote democracy and rule of law in Uganda.
The organisation has not had major changes since its inception, it has however grown from the initial one man led organisation to one with 11 (eleven) staff members at present. Four (04) are male and seven (07) are female.
The organisation started with providing legal support mainly of a strategic nature to individuals in need of support because of their work. It has however grown and now provides legal support to a wide range of activists including capacity building on different NGO laws, tax and labour laws, and other CSO specific laws. The organization provides strategic litigation mainly through support of cases that have an impact on society as a whole. These are supplemented by research and publication; legislative advocacy and general legal support for Human Rights Defenders.
ACHIEVEMENTS: Over the years Chapter Four has made a number of achievements. We have been able to successfully challenge the Anti Homosexuality Act which promoted discrimination for sexual minorities. The organisation has been able to provide legal support to about 230 HRDs in different cases across the country. Through research and legislative advocacy the organisation bill, where about 50%of the views generated were included in the law. In the same spirit the organization was a member of the technical committee selected by the Ministry of Internal Affairs to draft NGO regulations. In the last one year we developed capacity for 315 CSOs on issues under the NGO Act and the general legal operating environment. We were also able to support 57 CSOs in acquiring legal status (registration, acquisition of certificates, permits etc)and another 11 organizations in tax issues in 2017.
